page.title: 05RHUM SEA EAGLE REINTRODUCED
page.content: The Sea Eagle was once common throughout Scotland and Ireland. Last century it was persecuted by man until exterminated in 1916. The last nesting attempt on Rhum was in 1909 when the adults were shot and their eggs taken. In 1975 the Nature Conservancy Council began a project to reintroduce the Sea Eagle on Rhum. Each year from 4 to 10 eaglets are taken from nests in Norway and transported to Scotland by the R.A.F. After a couple of months in captivity on Rhum they are released but still provided with food until they disperse and fend for themselves. They feed on fish, seabirds and carrion, and take over 5 years to reach sexual maturity. A total of 72 have been released (up to 1984) and several pairs have now established and laid eggs. The first young was reared in 1985.
